node.title: VSCode Setup for MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'm currently setting up VSCode to work with MOOSE. I followed the instructions on the website and the things listed are working fine as far as I can tell.
However afterwards I received some include errors and was missing auto-completion so I searched the forum and found #25775. I used that as a reference and copied the c_cpp_properties.json. Then VSCode told me wasphit/HITInterpreter.h was missing as a dependency of several of my header files. I therefore added wasp to includePath. Currently my c_cpp_properties.json looks like this:
{
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Linux",
            "includePath": [
                "${workspaceFolder}",
                "${workspaceFolder}/build/header_symlinks",
                "${workspaceFolder}/../moose/framework/build/header_symlinks",
                "${workspaceFolder}/../moose/modules/module_loader/build/header_symlinks",
                "${workspaceFolder}/../moose/framework/contrib/boost/include",
                "${workspaceFolder}/../moose/framework/contrib/hit",
                "${workspaceFolder}/../moose/framework/contrib/wasp",
                "${HOME}/mambaforge3/envs/moose/include",
                "${HOME}/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/include",
                "${workspaceFolder}/../moose/framework/contrib/json/include"
            ],
            "defines": [],
            "compilerPath": "${HOME}/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin/mpicxx",
            "cStandard": "c11",
            "cppStandard": "c++17",
            "intelliSenseMode": "clang-x64",
            "compileCommands": "${workspaceFolder}/compile_commands.json",
            "browse": {
                "path": [
                    "${workspaceFolder}",
                    "${workspaceFolder}/build/header_symlinks",
                    "${workspaceFolder}/../moose/framework/build/header_symlinks",
                    "${workspaceFolder}/../moose/modules/module_loader/build/header_symlinks",
                    "${workspaceFolder}/../moose/framework/contrib/boost/include",
                    "${workspaceFolder}/../moose/framework/contrib/hit",
                    "${HOME}/mambaforge3/envs/moose/include",
                    "${HOME}/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh/include"
                ]
            }
        }
    ],
    "version": 4
}

The only warning left right now is a missing compile_commands.json referenced in the code above. However I haven't found a guide on this topic.
So my two questions are:

Where do I get compile_commands.json from?
Is my VSCode setup complete once I aquire said file?
@dschwen @loganharbour

To generate the file compile_commands.json, you can simply use (in your app directory):
make compile_commands.json
Thanks, everything seems to work fine now.

node.title: how to apply displacement on a deformed configration
node.bodyText:
Hi, everyone. From time=0 to time=1s, the boundary A has been deformed to u1 (it's a field). When time>1s, I want to add u2 (constant) on deformed boundary A with u1 field.
If I only add DirichletBC of u2 when time>1s, the previous u1 field will disappear.
It's not entirely clear to me what you want but you can use the Controls system to turn different objects on and off

You could rewrite the DirichletBC to apply u2 + u1 instead of just u2.
Just copy the value of u1 into an auxiliary variable using a CopyAux until t=1s (stop copying then)

node.title: Data Types
node.bodyText:
Hello,
If I couple a variable _grad_V as coupledGradient in a kernel, which is a vector data type I think, and compute the product _grad_V * _grad_V, does this retain its vector identity or does it become a real value scalar?
Thank you.
it becomes a scalar
Great it works thx!

node.title: Two solvers in the same input file
node.bodyText:
Hello,
Is it possible to use two different solvers in the same input file? For example, I want to use PJFNK for tensor mechanics and Newton for Porousflow in the same input file . Is there any example in this regard? Thanks.

As far as I know we don't have that capability right now. We just started supporting segregared nonlinear systems but the executioner support is not there yet. You can split the two systems using multiapps and then define the different solvers in each app.

node.title: Problem which undefined reference to `powf@GLIBC_2.27'  when compile MOOSE with libtorch
node.bodyText:
holle, MOOSEer!
I want to try using libtorch in MOOSE, But it can't make it work.The possible cause is that the version of libc on the system is too low, so I checked that libtorch_cpu.so relies on a version of libc that is higher than required.I don't know how to deal with it now, hope someone can help me a little.
Linking Executable /home/lwz/projects/dog/dog-opt...
/home/lwz/.conda/envs/moose2/bin/../lib/gcc/x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/10.4.0/../../../../x86_64-conda-linux-gnu/bin/ld: /home/lwz/projects/moose/framework/contrib/libtorch/lib/libtorch_cpu.so: undefined reference to `powf@GLIBC_2.27'

collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status

moose2) [lwz@ml64 dog]$ ldd /home/lwz/projects/moose/framework/contrib/libtorch/lib/libtorch_cpu.so
        linux-vdso.so.1 (0x00007ffdea165000)
        libc10.so => /home/lwz/projects/moose/framework/contrib/libtorch/lib/libc10.so (0x00007ff72eab2000)
        librt.so.1 => /lib64/librt.so.1 (0x00007ff71896e000)
        libgcc_s.so.1 => /lib64/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007ff718758000)
        libdl.so.2 => /lib64/libdl.so.2 (0x00007ff718554000)

        libc.so.6 => /usr/lib/libc.so.6 (0x00007ff7177b6000)
        /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007ff72e951000)

(moose2) [lwz@ml64 dog]$ /usr/lib/libc.so.6 -version
GNU C Library (GNU libc) stable release version 2.28.
Copyright (C) 2018 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
This is free software; see the source for copying conditions.
There is NO warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A
PARTICULAR PURPOSE.
Compiled by GNU CC version 10.2.0.
libc ABIs: UNIQUE IFUNC ABSOLUTE
For bug reporting instructions, please see:
<http://www.gnu.org/software/libc/bugs.html>.
You cannot use MOOSE on linux machines with our conda environment due to the conda compiler stack being built using an old GLIBC, we will work on this this fiscal year.
So the solution is: if you have a recent Linux-based operating system, just use the system compiler and compile petsc and libmesh yourself, then MOOSE.
If you are using INL HPC, we can give you containers as well.
Thank you, I don't use INL HPC, I will try to compile petsc and libmesh , then MOOSE.
Somehow I wasn't aware of this... Thanks for posting! I am not sure if Conda even has newer compiler versions available. But I will certainly poke around.

node.title: Implementing Custom Kernels (Mixed Formulation) with Heat Conduction as Example
node.bodyText:
Hi, I wanted to know the proper syntax for implementing this. I'm not getting converging results for this simple problem, and so I wanted to be sure my syntax was/is correct. Starting with the equations and their corresponding finite element discretizations:
Diffusion equation with variation taken wrt to T:

Considering the steady state case first, in my Kernel Header, I have this declaration:

And the residual computed like this:

A Fourier relationship between Flux and Temperature with variation taken wrt to q:

In the Kernel Header, I have:

And the residual computation:

Kernels block in input file

To my understanding this has been implemented correctly, but its not converging for what should be a very simple problem (a box with temperature ranging from 0 to 1) and so clearly I'm doing something wrong. Simulations failed with first order elements for all variables, and also with second order q variables. Could you please take a look?
Hi @richmondodufisan glancing over this, this looks good to me. If you wanted to share a github branch with your source and input, I could test it out and see if I can identify something problematic
How do I make your application?

Oh the whole application isn't what's on github, maybe that's what I should be doing instead. I just thought it would be redundant to create a new app anytime I wanted to add new but different physics. So instead I just created a repo with the custom objects for any user to be able to download and add to their app.
The repository I sent you has the source and header files (in the Kernels_and_Headers folder) needed which are to be copied to yourAppName/src/kernels and yourAppName/include/kernels respectively. And then you can make.
I added a script to change the app name before copying with usage Usage: ./Replace_App.sh <old_app_name> <new_app_name> where in this case old_app_name (name of my app) is "purple"

It would be better to create your own app. It can always be easily incorporated into others applications. For instance https://github.com/arfc/squirrel is an "app" but it's pulled in and used as a library by multiple other apps such as zapdos and moltres

So if you use -pc_type lu you will get an answer but it will look funny as shown below. What you need to add now are "implicit" boundary conditions to model the boundary terms coming from integration by parts. Right now you are implicitly setting the boundary terms for the "q equation" to 0 at all boundaries and for the "T equation" to 0 at the top and bottom boundaries
You will have no hope of getting a solution with boomeramg BTW for the Steady case since there is no diagonal for the temperature equation

Hmm I see, Will it make sense then, to not integrate the temperature term by parts in the q equation? Since the only flux/boundary term I actually want to use is the one from the t equation (i.e q.n = 0 on all natural boundaries)? I did try that but it still didn't converge. Or what boundary conditions would be closest to the usual formulation in ADHeatConduction?
Also, to be honest I don't know what most of those options in the Executioner mean, I should probably look into them further. I copied them from another input file when I was initially learning to use MOOSE with the basic understanding that if I used solve_type = 'PJFNK' and made my custom physics inherit from ADKernel, I wouldn't need to code my Jacobians myself thanks to automatic differentiation. I haven't looked in detail at what the rest of the options mean apart from the tolerance.
created the repository btw: https://github.com/richmondodufisan/purple

Hmm I see, Will it make sense then, to not integrate the temperature term by parts in the q equation?

Yes you can do that.

I did try that but it still didn't converge

Did you try it with -pc_type lu?

Actually, I tried it again (not integrating the T term in the q equation by parts) and this time it worked! The reason you gave made so much sense and I'm glad it converged, thank you! So it turns out it was something about those other options that was the reason it didn't converge before.

One thing that I did notice though, is the "outlier variable residual norms" in red. What does that mean?
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 3.060206e+00
 1 Nonlinear |R| = 3.005904e-05
 2 Nonlinear |R| = 2.818184e-10
 Solve Converged!
Currently Executing
  Finished Solving                                                                       [  6.71 s] [  157 MB]

Outlier Variable Residual Norms:
  temperature: 2.803203e-10

So it turns out it was something about those other options that was the reason it didn't converge before.

Yea boomeramg works best for symmetric positive definite matrices and your system is indefinite due to the missing diagonal in the T equation so boomeramg will not work well. Generally when debugging I always use -pc_type lu since that is basically a direct inversion of the preconditioning matrix, so it is the strongest preconditioner you can apply and will work with all systems. It just has very poor efficiency for large matrices.

One thing that I did notice though, is the "outlier variable residual norms" in red. What does that mean?

It just means that it's residual is larger than the other variable by a significant margin. But you've dropped the overall residual norm by 10 orders of magnitude so I would not worry about it.

node.title: Transient instability in high flowrate model
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I have spent a couple of months now trying to deal with transient instability in a model with high flowrate (need to go up to 1000 L/min, giving an inlet velocity as 140 m/s). I have simplified the geometry significantly and created an MWE which reproduces the issue. The figure below shows the pressure drop increasing exponentially from about t=0.05 s to eventually crash at t~1.61 s.

Following the guidelines in "Troubleshooting failed solves" page, I have changed the initial condition from velocity=0 to one based on inlet velocity and flow divisions, I also fixed the diameter as constant. I also scaled the variables to improve the solution. The convergence seems fine throughout the whole simulation (see log below):
Time Step 16100, time = 1.61, dt = 0.0001
    |residual|_2 of individual variables:
         junction-728:rhoEV: 0.954486
         junction-728:rhoV:  0.00838734
         junction-728:rhouV: 42.7522
         junction-728:rhovV: 19.5515
         junction-728:rhowV: 4.37464
         junction-733:rhoEV: 5.49613
         junction-733:rhoV:  0.00634548
         junction-733:rhouV: 24.375
         junction-733:rhovV: 110.444
         junction-733:rhowV: 288.872
         rhoA:               0.0411604
         rhoEA:              0.0550817
         rhouA:              0.060198
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 3.138465e+02
      0 Linear |R| = 3.138465e+02
      1 Linear |R| = 2.163226e+02
      2 Linear |R| = 1.535664e+00
      3 Linear |R| = 2.392176e-01
      4 Linear |R| = 5.622355e-03
      5 Linear |R| = 1.110909e-05
    |residual|_2 of individual variables:
         junction-728:rhoEV: 0.0501407
         junction-728:rhoV:  3.20005e-05
         junction-728:rhouV: 1.77731
         junction-728:rhovV: 1.16674
         junction-728:rhowV: 0.00863554
         junction-733:rhoEV: 0.54433
         junction-733:rhoV:  0.00175378
         junction-733:rhouV: 1.42963
         junction-733:rhovV: 9.53675
         junction-733:rhowV: 0.163855
         rhoA:               0.000152264
         rhoEA:              0.000190096
         rhouA:              0.000191392
 1 Nonlinear |R| = 9.891371e+00
      0 Linear |R| = 9.891371e+00
      1 Linear |R| = 6.471072e-02
      2 Linear |R| = 8.884682e-03
      3 Linear |R| = 3.197219e-04
      4 Linear |R| = 2.780930e-07
    |residual|_2 of individual variables:
         junction-728:rhoEV: 3.04345e-06
         junction-728:rhoV:  7.24824e-09
         junction-728:rhouV: 2.56967e-06
         junction-728:rhovV: 4.03091e-06
         junction-728:rhowV: 9.483e-09
         junction-733:rhoEV: 0.000150371

         junction-733:rhouV: 0.000148026
         junction-733:rhovV: 0.000999644
         junction-733:rhowV: 1.02263e-05
         rhoA:               6.19741e-08
         rhoEA:              1.52932e-07
         rhouA:              8.7553e-08
 2 Nonlinear |R| = 1.021738e-03
      0 Linear |R| = 1.021738e-03
      1 Linear |R| = 1.061215e-05
      2 Linear |R| = 4.211359e-07
      3 Linear |R| = 1.911311e-08
      4 Linear |R| = 3.632826e-12
    |residual|_2 of individual variables:
         junction-728:rhoEV: 2.11386e-13
         junction-728:rhoV:  1.88877e-14
         junction-728:rhouV: 4.01883e-11
         junction-728:rhovV: 4.57945e-12
         junction-728:rhowV: 1.66978e-13
         junction-733:rhoEV: 1.39089e-12
         junction-733:rhoV:  2.88641e-14
         junction-733:rhouV: 1.24345e-13
         junction-733:rhovV: 1.33582e-12
         junction-733:rhowV: 7.95808e-13
         rhoA:               1.56777e-12
         rhoEA:              2.15145e-12
         rhouA:              2.16606e-12
 3 Nonlinear |R| = 4.064838e-11
 Solve Converged!

Outlier Variable Residual Norms:
  junction-728:rhouV: 4.018830e-11

But not long after, the time-step becomes very small and the simulation crashes. I thought maybe this was due to the fluid properties which I fixed as constant becoming less accurate as pressure and temperature change non-homogeneously, but when I changed to Water97FluidProperties the simulation diverges really quick (within a few steps due to issue with line search), so I guess that is a different problem and I should focus on this one first.
I have attached the input file. Hopefully someone could manage to provide some assistance. Happy to provide more information, log files or anything else that could be useful.
Best wishes,
Josh
coolant-simulation-for-github.i.txt

Seems that when I increase the volume at a VolumeJunction from 9e-7 to 9e-4 (just a random test) that everything is stable. Not sure if this is the underlying or is maybe just masking it (something to do with variable scaling in junctions).
How should the volume be calculated? In my input files I have been treating the junction as a sphere with the radius equal to that of the upstream branch, and calculating volume of the sphere (which gave 9e-7).
Increasing from 9e-7 to 9e-6 seems to delay the issue, but still arises after a while.
@joshuahansel

I tried your input file without the loop 728-784-791-733, and it finishes fine, so it's the loop causing issues. In particular, I think the formulation of VolumeJunction1Phase needs improvement. We've had issues with this junction in the past but have not had the funding to tackle it, despite it being a pretty critical component. The only other junction that can handle multiple connections is JunctionParallelChannels1Phase, but this of course requires that channels be parallel, which is not your situation. I'm going to try and look at the volume junction formulation soon, but I can't guarantee a solution soon.
I found something that I can try, so I'm going to try it now. You should hopefully hear from me by the end of the day.

Well I implemented the change (I think correctly...), but I get a lot of nonlinear convergence difficulty on your test problem, even after exploring it for a few hours. At this point, I think I would need to properly fund the task because apparently it is not a quick fix. I made an issue here: #25958. I will see if I can get this work funded.
Yes, the loop is the problem I found too. Thanks for your time.

To answer your question about junction volume, yes, that's how we typically do it. You could also choose a sphere with the same surface area as the sum of the connected cross-sectional areas - maybe that would be better. A tip: you can display the junction variables by setting Outputs/disable_scalars_in_console=false. One thing that was strange that I saw in my experimenting was that the variable rhoV was going up significantly (in a relative sense) in some cases.
In case it's useful, here's an input file with the same general setup:
bypass_loop.txt
It appears to give a good solution. You can modify it gradually toward your input file to see what particular thing causes things to break down. That would be helpful to us (maybe to you too).
See the issue referenced above for an update. I will try the suggested change and see if this improves things.

Thanks for the answer and the case setup file.
Interesting point raised in the issue regarding the tangential momentum. When I was setting up the MWE, I found that if I remove the junctions "junction-232" and "junction-14" (pretty much the bends in the pipe attached to inlet and outlet, which would create a straight path from the inlet to the volumejunction, and volumejunction to outlet) then the simulation was stable. I could not figure out why, so I guess this is maybe related.

Good news: I've reworked the volume junction and I tried your input file again, and it ran well. Got to steady state at 1.25 seconds - took 11 time steps. Solution looks plausible.
I have one more thing to try out on it, and then I'll put up a merge request.
Great news, thanks! I look forward to testing it.

I'm getting waylaid by other work, and this will take some work like documentation and testing before it can be reviewed and merged, but I put up the merge request as a draft if you urgently need the branch for your work: #26046.
I have tested it on the MWE and the more complex case, both seem to be working well. Thanks a lot for your help! I will mark this as answered.

node.title: Adaptive mesh refinement
node.bodyText:
Hello Moose community,
I am studying adaptive mesh with Moose. There are several indicators we can use like Jump Indicator, Gradient Jump Indicator of a variable. However, I want to study with the simplest one, the indicator is the variable itself, the element will be refined when its value higher than a threadhold. I wonder how to do it? I've tried with Moose variable like the code below but it doesn't work.
[Adaptivity]
  marker = errorfrac
  steps = 1
  max_h_level = 4
  [Indicators]
    [error]
      type = MooseVariable       #GradientJumpIndicator or ValueJumpIndicator
      variable = c 
      scale_by_flux_faces = true
    []
  []
  [Markers]
    [errorfrac]
      type = ErrorFractionMarker
      indicator = error
      refine = 0.5 #cut value
      coarsen = 0
    []
  []
[]
Did you try specifying no indicator block and instead passing the name of the variable to the parameter. (The variable being defined normally as an auxvariable or Variable as usual)

I have not tried, but something like this maybe?
[Adaptivity]
  marker = errorfrac
  steps = 1
  max_h_level = 4
  [Markers]
    [errorfrac]
      type = ErrorFractionMarker
      indicator = error
      refine = 0.5 #cut value
      coarsen = 0
    []
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [error]
  []
[]

It doesn't work. Anyway, I found out a way to define it as an analytical solution of a function

[Functions]
  [solution]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = x
  []
[]

[Adaptivity]
  marker = errorfrac
  steps = 1
  max_h_level = 4
  [Indicators]
    [error]
      type = AnalyticalIndicator
      variable = c
      function = solution
    []
  []
  [Markers]
    [errorfrac]
      type = ErrorFractionMarker
      coarsen = 0.0
      indicator = error
      refine = 0.1
    []
  []
[]

node.title: Discrepancy between Peacock and Paraview
node.bodyText:
Hello! I am very new to MOOSE and am trying to learn how to use it by following the online 12-hour tutorial recorded in Summer 2020.
I am currently working on Step 5 but I am concerned that I have done something that is affecting my Paraview.
When I run the Step 5a from my command line using peacock (~/projects/moose/python/peacock/peacock -I step5a_transient.i) I obtain the following graphic:

this matches what is shown in the video, as the temperature is increasing from 300 to 350.
However, when I attempt to open the output file in Paraview using the command 'open' from my Terminal (I am using a Mac), I obtain the following as my initial and final time steps




Does anyone have any explanation for why this is occurring or how to fix it? I apologize if this is a very simple question!
Thank you for your time and consideration.
When you are on last image (ie Time =1), press rescale to Data range and see what happens.
Thank you so much! That fixed it.

node.title: Gauge Invariance
node.bodyText:
Hi there,
I am wondering how MOOSE handles gauge invariance. When solving a set of problems that has gauge variance should the user select a predefined gauge to work within, or will gauge invariance be handled by the test function?
And subsequently, should the user define a gauge, will this affect the results/convergence of the kernels due to some interaction with the test function?
This might be one that @cticenhour might know the answer to.
Any help would be much appreciated!
Many thanks,
Gillian

We don't currently have a model example that applies a gauge and solves for a vector potential in the MOOSE electromagnetics module, as Maxwell's equations are manipulated into coupled wave equations and solved directly for the electric and magnetic vector fields. Adding a Coulomb gauge, in particular, is something that is on my roadmap for the coming months of development for a research project, but isn't ready yet.
The gauge invariance isn't handled by the test function. We use a first-order Nedelec vector basis from libMesh for most problems, and the recent introduction of Raviart-Thomas elements in libMesh is something I also want to explore. So, if you wanted to attempt to define a gauge in your problem, the test function should not affect the results or convergence (at least in a way specific to the gauge, I believe). @lindsayad or @roystgnr may be able to give some insight on the libMesh test functions and correct me if I am wrong here.

Ok great, thank you very much for the help!
I will keep an eye out for the addition of a Coulomb gauge, and I will impose my own gauge for now.
All the best,
Gillian
Without spending too much time re-learning gauge invariance, I would need to see the PDEs you want to solve

Disclaimer: I know basically nothing about gauge invariance.  It might be wise to stop reading this comment after that sentence.
Is the idea here that we're solving for a divergence-free vector field like the magnetic field B, and ∇·B=0 implies that there exists a potential-vector field A such that B=∇×A, so we'd like to be able to just solve for A directly and get a strongly divergence-free B, but the problem is that A is only unique up to some transformation (like adding ∇Ω for some smooth Ω) that changes A but not B?
If you're solving a problem like that in 2D, you can use a variable defined with one of the libMesh C¹ scalar-valued elements (CLOUGH works on general grids; HERMITE is more efficient if you have a cartesian mesh), treat its values as if they were magnitudes of a vector field in the z direction, take the curl of that field to get a divergence-free vector field in the xy plane, and the kernel of that operation is just the constant fields so you can add a single extra residual term to pin the value at one point to get a well-defined potential.
If you're solving a problem like that in 3D, you could still use three HERMITE variables to give you components of a C¹ vector field, and take the curl of that to get a divergence-free 3D vector field ... but now the kernel isn't a simple one-dimensional thing, it's dimensionality is something like a third of your degrees of freedom.  Maybe there's some efficient way to constrain that and keep going, but when I looked at that problem during my PhD I was advised to find something easier instead.
